Meh... To go as far to speculate that the gut bacteria are possibly producing a directly anabolic compound is a bit of a stretch at this stage. What seems to me as a more sensible speculation is that a healthy microbiome simply facilitates more efficient digestion, assimilation, and partitioning of the nutrients which we know directly lead to muscle protein synthesis. A healthy gut microbiome is also involved in producing the inflammatory compounds needed to stimulate the mTor response. I think a lack of deficiency in these areas is a much more likely scenario than an undiscovered direct anabolic mechanism produced by the gut microbiome.

anecdotal evidence is hardly evidence, but i'll still share my anecdotes here:
this definitely supports what happened to me, i work out 3 times a week, and for 6-7 months couldn't lose weight or gain muscle. i counted calories, didn't go over 1800 (rarely even above 1500) except for once a month (and even then it was just by a bit).

started focusing on gut bacteria, cut out any sugars i could, planned meals based on cultivating healthier patterns, ended up eating more overall usually 1800-2200 calories a day, exercised the same amount. but the pounds just fell off, the muscle appeared, it was like black magic!

i'm sure other factors had to be involved, and i'd trust a full study more than my singular experience any day, but it really did feel like a switch was flipped with just that one change.

These findings appear consistent with my own experience of very intense chemotherapy followed by tumor resection including a sternotomy, all of which left me with decreasing exercise but a $&*t ton of antibiotics and antifungals over several months for the near-constant opportunistic infections. I stopped counting when I reached a loss of 50 pounds during chemo. A couple of months after my surgery my weight had recovered but it clearly wasn't mostly muscle as it had been before everything. Nope, it was soft, squishy fat. And I had no stamina. That was ten years ago, and while I've managed to get healthier and in the last few months finally lose visceral fat, I still haven't recovered any muscle. I feel like all the different probiotics I've taken have helped with my general health but that I've never restored the population of gut bacteria and other local biomes that made muscle gain so easy for me pre-chemo. I'd JUMP at the opportunity to volunteer for a study in which I could get a poop transplant from a young, healthy, muscular athlete to see if it made a difference and by how much. The findings discussed in this video don't PROVE my hypothesis, but it sure feels good (sorta) that I may have been correct—though it would be even better if I had access to corrective medical care.

As a bodybuilder & ex trainer, I think this is a flawed study & non-sequitur by people who don’t understand hypertrophy.

The discrepancy can be explained by one group not needing its energy devoted to recovering its gut bacteria vs the one whose energy can be completely devoted to rebuilding muscle & already having gut bacteria to make use of nutrients. This is exactly why drinking is antithetical to bodybuilding; in addition to no nutrients & the extra & useless calories, you’re now tasking the body with having the liver devote energy to ridding the body of poison (alcohol; low grade poison). This essentially throws away the workout. Not entirely, but enough that it’s inadvisable.

but yeah, it seems like "good poo factory means better gains" might be kinda side stepping an actual conclusion that makes sense. like how some study linked autism to weak gut bacteria being interpreted as the "poor gut bacteria causes autism" (which i think is obvious misinterpretation), i think the relationship is more... that diet, overall health, and even hygiene, are the major factors, and that the gut bacteria is the direct result of supplying those colonies so they can flourish, which leads to better nutrient absorbtion. which, the "bad gut bacteria causes autism" is really a mirrored reality of autistic people often have limited and particular diets that can, over time, impact gut health. the important factor being diet, and not that gut bacteria is mystical. in other words, poor gut bacteria is a symptom, not the cause.

One thing to note is that the scientists compared an impeded microbiome with a normal one. But that's missing the possibility of an enhanced one, which is what any supplements based on such findings will promote itself as doing. Just cos a normal microbiome beats an impeded one doesn't mean an enhanced one will beat the normal one. It's possible it won't work any better, or that it's just not possible to enhance the microbiome much higher than normal, which would make any supplements essentially a waste of money for anyone who doesn't have any actual gut problems. That won't stop the marketers from promoting it to everyone though...
